timeseries.models

Class RandomWalk

  • java.lang.Object
    • timeseries.models.RandomWalk
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Model

    public final class RandomWalk
extends Object
implements Model
    A model for a random walk process. Some important characteristics of the random walk are that the process variance increases with time (non-stationarity) and that the optimal forecast at any point in the future is equal to the last observed value.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      RandomWalk(TimeSeries observed)
      Create a new random walk model from the given time series of observations.

      • pointForecast

        public TimeSeries pointForecast(int steps)
        Description copied from interface: Model
        Produce a time series of point forecasts from this model up to the given number of steps ahead.

        To obtain additional information about the forecast, such as prediction intervals, use the Model.forecast(int, double) method and the resulting Forecast object.

        Specified by:
        pointForecast in interface Model
        Parameters:
        steps - the number of time periods ahead to forecast.
        Returns:
        a time series of point forecasts from this model up to the given number of steps ahead.

      • forecast

        public Forecast forecast(int steps,
                         double alpha)
        Description copied from interface: Model
        Produce a new forecast up to the given number of steps with the given α significance level for computing prediction intervals.
        Specified by:
        forecast in interface Model
        Parameters:
        steps - the number of time periods ahead to forecast.
        alpha - the probability that a future observation will fall outside the associated (1 - α)100% prediction interval, given that the model is "correct". Note that the correctness of the model often comes with a high degree of uncertainty and this should be taken into account when making decisions. In other words, the provided prediction intervals will often be overly optimistic.
        Returns:
        a new forecast up to the given number of steps ahead with the given significance level.
